title.value: AU Biological Sex Assigned at Birth

publisher.value: Health Level Seven Australia (Patient Administration WG)

description.value: A person’s biological sex is based upon their sex characteristics, such as their chromosomes, hormones and reproductive organs. A person’s sex can change over the course of their lifetime and may differ from their sex assigned at birth. Sex assigned at birth refers to what was determined by sex characteristics observed at birth or infancy, including genital and chromosome composition. Sex assigned at birth is captured once for a person and is not expected to change within their lifetime

short.value: Sex assigned at birth based on sex characteristics observed at birth or infancy

definition.value: Sex assigned at birth refers to what was determined by sex characteristics including genital and chromosome composition observed at birth or infancy. Sex assigned at birth is captured once for a person and is not expected to change within their lifetime, even if the person’s sex changes and is different from the sex assigned at birth.

comment.value: See [AIHW Person – sex concept](https://meteor.aihw.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/635233), [Australian Government Guidelines on the Recognition of Sex and Gender](https://www.ag.gov.au/rights-and-protections/publications/australian-government-guidelines-recognition-sex-and-gender), and [ABS Standard for Sex, Gender, Variations of Sex Characteristics and Sexual Orientation Variables, 2020](https://www.abs.gov.au/statistics/standards/standard-sex-gender-variations-sex-characteristics-and-sexual-orientation-variables/latest-release).

To record a sex at birth of a person born with genetic, hormonal or physical sex characteristics that are not typically female or male, coding.code should be 32570691000036108 \| Intersex \|. When the biological sex at birth cannot be cannot be determined, coding.code should be 32570681000036106 \| Indeterminate sex\|.
